Topic.Title: AMZN now worth the same as INTC...

Message.Msg: Interesting comparison. With the 3.9% yield and some built-in inflation protection, Intel looks a whole lot better than a treasury right now. That said, I think the whole market is a bad bet. I'm being very careful with any long positions right now. Analysts are revising the S&P 500 earnings estimate this quarter to -2% growth. The fiscal cliff is around the corner. Government debt is 8x revenue and much of it can never be repaid without severe austerity and prolonged recession. Interest rates have nowhere to go but up. Taxes have nowhere to go but up. There also is heightened risks of war with the increased economic turmoil around the world. World populations are getting restless. Concentration of income is at an all-time high.

Message.Title: What is the model here?
Message.Msg: Amazon appears to have given up on the sales tax issue now that it is building distribution centers all over. They have to collect sales tax in all states where they have distribution. Given that, what real advantage do they have over the brick and mortar retailers. They definitely don't have the brands. No manufacturer with any branding power and dealer network is going to sell on Amazon at a discounted price. The only strategy appears to be same day delivery. They want you to be able to order on-line and have your order at your doorstep same day. Problem is, that actually involves two major disadvantages. First, you incur higher transportation costs. Second, the customers can't see the product before they buy it, and returns are a hassle. In my view, AMZN's retail model is dead now that they've lost the sales tax advantage. It is headed for a slow steady decline at some point. The cloud will be dominated by a few ecosystems pretty soon, and those will be the players with a lot of capital for investment, which AMZN just doesn't have. I'd only about 20x earnings for this bookseller.

Topic.Title: Indecisive today.

Message.Msg: Billy_bres: I agree that branded products will not be sold at a discount. But how can you tell which branded product to buy by just looking at it? I prefer reading customer reviews and paying full price to looking at a display model. Brick and mortar stores are the dead model. Book stores and big box retailers are proof.

Topic.Title: Why I should continue buying from Amazon

Message.Msg: If you are a person that like to see the item you are buying before you buy it, then Amazon is not the place to buy anymore. Most people before they would buy a big ticket item would go to Best Buy to see it on display. Best Buy was Amazon's showroom. Now that they are more on equal footing, in that customers will now have to pay taxes at Amazon, Unless you can get the item at a serious discount from Amazon, then you might well buy at Best Buy while you are there looking. The savings you had at Amazon may no longer be there. I think Amazon's margins will be further squeezed.

Message.Title: Only One Thing That Can Transform Amazon
Message.Msg: Only one thing would serve to turn amazon into a efficient cash and profit machine; wall street holding them properly accountable. This ingrained culture of spending to gain sales regardless of efficiency discipline will only be broken by a wicked sell-off of the stock. Playing for a longer term time frame is generally a healthy strategic posture to take when managing a start-up but Amazon has slipped into very bad habits. Each spending phase ends up with lower and lower margins and longer investment cycles. The latest "investment " cycle is full of highly paid engineers, employees of all strips and massive infrastructure with sticky ongoing cost commitment. Wall street is keeping the patient well fed and medicated and hopes for heeling but the patient doesn't realize they are sick!

Topic.Title: an education please

Message.Msg: What most people in the market don't understand is that tops need high volume to come in,and we had that Friday. What increases the likelyhood of a top is the most market leaders put extensions into that high into Friday thru today. Now the market has a ceiling or roof at 1475 and tried to better that today and turned was turned back quickly. With the extension and high volume I doubt we see 1475 again for some time. Be watchful!
